"But the great security against a gradual concentration of the several powers in the same department consists in giving to those who administer each department the necessary constitutional means and personal motives to resist encroachments of the others. The provision for defense must in this, as in all other cases, be made commensurate to the danger of attack. Ambition must be made to counteract ambition. . . . It may be a reflection on human nature that such devices should be necessary to control the abuses of government. But what is government itself but the greatest of all reflections on human nature? If men were angels, no government would be necessary. If angels were to govern men, neither external nor internal controls on government would be necessary."

—From The Federalist, No. 51

hotspots.hotspot: The Constitution must provide a means for one branch of government to resist seizures of power by the other branches.
Humans by nature want power, and the Constitution must protect one branch of government by giving it sufficient power to counteract the other branches' powers.
Humans will always be motivated by power and, therefore, must have written rules to govern their actions.

activity.text:
Article I: The Legislative Branch

  • Section 1: Creates a bicameral legislature called Congress, with a House of Representatives and a Senate.
  • Section 2: States the terms of office for members of the House of Representatives, how to fill vacant spots, and names the officers of the House. Also gives the House the power of impeachment.
  • Section 3: States the terms of office for members of the Senate, the vice president's role in the Senate, and names the officers. Also gives the Senate the role of holding impeachment trials and states the punishment for impeachment.
  • Section 4: Establishes rules for congressional elections.
  • Section 5: Establishes rules for sessions of Congress.
  • Section 6: Authorizes payment for members of Congress and creates rules for payment.
  • Section 7: Establishes how legislation will be created and passed.
  • Section 8: Enumerates the powers of Congress.
  • Section 9: Describes the powers denied to Congress.
  • Section 10: Describes the powers denied to the states.

"In republican government, the legislative authority necessarily predominates. The remedy for this inconveniency is to divide the legislature into different branches; and to render them, by different modes of election and different principles of action, as little connected with each other as the nature of their common functions and their common dependence on the society will admit. It may even be necessary to guard against dangerous encroachments by still further precautions."

—From The Federalist, No. 51

"Energy in the Executive is a leading character in the definition of good government. It is essential to the protection of the community against foreign attacks; it is not less essential to the steady administration of the laws; to the protection of property against those irregular and high-handed combinations which sometimes interrupt the ordinary course of justice; to the security of liberty against the enterprises and assaults of ambition, of faction, and of anarchy."

—From The Federalist, No. 70

content.text:
"The judiciary . . . has no influence over either the sword or the purse; no direction either of the strength or of the wealth of the society, and can take no active resolution whatever. It may truly be said to have neither FORCE nor WILL, but merely judgment; and must ultimately depend upon the aid of the executive arm even for the efficacy of its judgments.

This simple view of the matter suggests several important consequences. It proves incontestably that the judiciary is beyond comparison the weakest of the three departments of power."

—From The Federalist, No. 78
